author: {'steamid': '76561199249239770', 'num_games_owned': 89, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1707639105}
review:
Seeing as this was released in 2014, I have expected a quality of that same year, given Artifex Mundi's probably old game engine, etc.. I only played for roughly more than two hours.

It was straightforward, voice acting is actually one of the engaging one in my opinion. You can also keep pressing your left click to speed up the dialogues. I hoped they kept it that way for future releases. Recent Artifex Mundi games reuse voice actors. The puzzles varied from the latest releases as well, meaning if someone plays the recent releases and play this game after, the puzzles in this game aren't similar. The achievements are also easy to get.

However, as such positives entail, the game is also bugged with criticisms. The story is straightforward and only a few actions can be done in one scene. Some animations of taking items were clunky and robotic, and the scenes were blurry most of the times so it was difficult to see the items. The character movements seem flat, and the ending is pretty much just [b][i]Poof! You saved the day![/i][/b]

This is a personal [u]6/10[/u] hit due to its current quality, but I would still recommend this for others that belong in a specific niche. This niche are people who may want to check it out, and if you're in for some straightforward story with a hit of nostalgia or simply just a Hidden Object Game player at heart who wants to play every single one of it in Steam, then this game is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561199010042150', 'num_games_owned': 3874, 'num_reviews': 2454, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1709094283}
review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045411242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1701025380}
review:
[u]Recommendation[/u]: A run-of-the-mill Artifex Mundi game, with everything that entails: an absolutely bonkers nonsensical story advanced by playing a lot of hidden object scenes. The novelty of some of the mechanics makes up for some of the deficiencies in the gameplay.

[u]Critique[/u]: This is a remaster of an early Artifex Mundi game. Comparing it to other early games from the studio, I feel like I have a pretty good idea what has been updated. The cut scenes now have the creepy deepfake animation that the studio has used so much, where a static image is stretched and squashed to give the appearance of movement, rather than using more traditional 2D or 3D animation. Voice acting has been added, and I suspect that the graphics on many of the mini-games have been revamped. But the hidden object scenes are definitely old-school Artifex Mundi, where most of the challenge is accomplished by the difficulty of spotting items in grainy, low-detail images in very cluttered scenes. It doesn't help that there's frequently also imprecise names of the things you are trying to find: "candle" could mean a candle, or it could mean a candelabra, or a candlestick...basically anything related to a candle. So you often don't really know what you're looking for; the words are more [i]clues[/i] that you have to [i]interpret[/i], rather than lists of [i]objects[/i] you need to [i]find[/i]. That said, I liked the progression and flow of this game: gathering the seven rings in the different eras gave the game a fun, cyclical feel AND gave a sense of progression: you always know how far you are in the game when you know that there are seven parts.

The story is typically hilarious nonsense. At this point, having played so many hidden object games, I welcome the ridiculousness and look forward to how each game might top the previous ones in their B-movie drama, bizarre plot twists, flat vocal performances, and broken English. That said, because I played the second and third games first, the story here seemed like an unnecessary rehash, or an inferior prequel, to those games, which tell the story of the danger to the future much more effectively.

[u]Review[/u]: Vivian's dad has been kidnapped by a Borg weirdo. Everybody has creepy deepfake animation that is particularly bad. [spoiler]Advised by a sentient crystal ball that she finds among her father's effects, Vivian has to travel through several centuries to retrieve magic Ambrose rings. Each time period consists of three or four location screens and a few hidden object puzzles. This is to get the next time period's magic ring. Then, returning to the lab with the ring for the next time period, you add the ring to a time machine. Then you go into a storage room to perform another hidden object scene, collecting various items ostensibly to gather artifacts from that ring's time period. There are two views of this storage room (left and right), which you will see again and again and again as you proceed through the game...though the objects you are trying to find have been moved around each time. Then, when you have all the items, you put them in a hopper on the time machine to unlock the portal to go to that century. When you have done that, you have to solve a "find the seven differences" puzzle to activate the time machine. You do all of these things seven times, once for each time period. In the end, the borg weirdo is actually a benign time traveler who was looking to get help from your dad, who was so absent-minded that he got lost, rather than getting kidnapped. So the game ends on a denouement that sort of sets up the second and third game.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561197985130407', 'num_games_owned': 818, 'num_reviews': 198, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1700523000}
review:
[i]Game native resolution: 1366x768[/i]

No, do  not play this game.  The gameplay is as basic as possible and it's so very, very, very old.

One of the pleasures of hidden object adventure games is looking at beautiful artwork.  This game is so terribly [i]un[/i]-pleasant to look at.

This is one of those ancient HOAGs that has been "remastered."  I don't know anything about the original game, but I can tell it was a 4:3 aspect ratio game.  For this version, they made the mistake of having it widescreen by default, causing the background images to appear horizontally stretched.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3078325852

Don't play this game, but if you do, [b]I strongly suggest that you run the game at a 4:3 aspect ratio, rather than 16:9.[/b]  The only way to do this is change the desktop to a resolution with 4:3 aspect ratio.  I used 1024x768, which is the 4:3 equivalent of 1366x768.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3078326245

Grungy, grimy, aliased, grainy, stinky low res images make hidden object scenes much more challenging than they should be.  Many objects are nearly invisible!  It's not even just the very poor image quality, these developers were sneaky jerks with hiding stuff!

The puzzles are mostly decent, but some are gnarly and infuriated me.

Don't play this game, but if you do, keep this official walkthrough on hand: https://www.bigfishgames.com/blog/walkthroughs/time-mysteries-inheritance.html

I had purchased the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/2582/Time_Mysteries_Collection/]Time Mysteries Bundle[/url], so I will review the next two games.  I hope I will not suffer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020225761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1691210254}
review:
Bad. I checked other reviews and noticed that people claim that it is bad because old. But I disagree - it's just bad. Age is not the case here. It's just lazy, boring and low quality product. Let's check all it's aspects one by one.

Story. Dumb and primitive. Even by HoG standards. This entire 'time travelling' thing is not developed anyhow. You are just randomly jumping into different time periods. Characters? -  absolutely unremarkable. To meet and to forget. The main caracters or the secondary ones - doesn't matter.

Gameplay and visuals. Yes, I put them together, because poor visuals also affect the gameplay. Local HoGs are very boring and repetative. Each time, after you visit new time periods, you come back to the same location and repeat the same boring HoGs. And completing them is not that easy task, because due to poor visuals, you often have to guess what exactly you see in front of you. Some locations, like a parlor, look absolutely ugly - it's just overstretched low-res jpeg.

Voiceacting and animations. They are not just mediocre, they also exist separately from one another. Sometimes you can see a character speaking without any animations. Another time - dude clearly says something and makes some gesticulation, but you can't hear anything. Bugged? Forgot to voice it? - no idea.

Something good? - YES! Suddenly - fascinating medieval BGMs. Really cool. Honestly, they deserve a better game. But in the end - this is 'NO' from me. Only if you want to get it for cards and achievements - grab it on good sale. Yes, this game is a part of a serie, but local events are barely related to other games, so you can safely ignore it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198835430528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1692722423}
review:
A below average hidden object game that is fully voice acted and animated.

Although the game is a remaster, graphics still look very dated.  In most hidden object scenes it is quite challenging to recognize items due to the blurriness.

The game has animated cutscenes but their quality is below average, some of the characters look downright creepy.

Sounds and the background music are good, but voice acting is not. Some lines sound as if they were recorded using a 
text-to-speech software.

The game is very difficult. Some minigames require quite some time to crack.

The story is uninteresting and repetitive, the hidden object scenes and the locations are boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986657824', 'num_games_owned': 984, 'num_reviews': 229, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1691437088}
review:
A ver es un juego muy justito, justito...desde luego, de los peores que he jugado de este tipo. Es verdad que si quieres juegos de objetos ocultos, aquÃ­ no tienes nada mÃ¡s...prÃ¡cticamente todo el juego es de eso, casi sin ninguna dinÃ¡mica de las que suelen tener ahora este tipo de juegos...lo cual hace que sea bastante monÃ³tono. El argumento, si bien no suele ser una gran caracterÃ­stica de estos juegos, aquÃ­ directamente no le han dedicado ni dos minutos...estÃ¡ todo metido con calzador para ponerte a encontrar cosas y algÃºn que otro puzzle.

MÃºsica pasable y grÃ¡ficos, no suelen ser necesarios en estos juegos y es verdad que ya tiene un tiempo...pero es que son malos, malos...ademÃ¡s, la optimizaciÃ³n no estÃ¡ muy bien conseguida y todo el juego tiene un efecto como emborronado que te recomiendo que descanses cada tanto la vista o acabarÃ¡s algo mareado. Si eres completista, cuidado, porque nada indica que si resuelves los juegos de objetos ocultos con los puzzles alternativos, pierdas el logro de obtenerlos sin pista, ya que los considera pistas...con lo que te tocarÃ¡ rejugar el juego que, aunque cortito (casi lo Ãºnico bueno), pues no parece necesario.

En definitiva, hay muchos juegos mejores de este estilo y mÃ¡s entretenidos y aunque para "desconectar" un ratillo entre juegos, siempre vienen bien...probablemente emplees tu tiempo mejor en otras entregas, a no ser que lo encuentres muy rebajado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119665625', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1687009124}
review:
[b]In short[/b]
This is a [i]tentative[/i] recommendation to buy it [i]on sale[/i] for folks who:
[list]
[*] love to play HOGs and may need to fill the void after running out of Artifex Mundi games to play
[*] want to see the "beginnings" of Artifex Mundi's journey into HOGs (as this is one of their first games)
[/list]

[b]In slightly-less-short[/b]
The story was [i]illogical[/i]
I personally don't have any big hate towards a bad or slightly illogical story in a HOG - I feel like they are often hit or miss when I try to check out a new game.
[i]However[/i], this one did manage to disappoint me. I personally love a good villain, so the idea that [spoiler]the supposed villain (kidnapper) you were chasing throughout the game was actually just some misunderstood guy trying to get help to save the world[/spoiler] ... it left me disappointed and kind of bored, to say the least.

The puzzles were [i]fine[/i].
I genuinely got excited at having to play some games of Mastermind for two of the puzzles, although I can imagine it would be a bit difficult to grasp the mechanics if you are not familiar with Mastermind in the first place.
Other than that, most of the puzzles felt a bit lack-lustre, and a majority of the HO scenes really irritated my eyes, because they were much too bright and the lighting kept pulsing (which I'm really hoping doesn't carry over into the second and third game in the series ;-;). Also... why so many spoons and flutes? Please explain.

The visuals were [i]unintentionally funny[/i]
As always, we have the well-known style that permeates every Artifex Mundi HOG. Beautiful and classic; it gives me a sense of comfort and nostalgia whenever I start a new game and see it. Except... this time it's less refined.
I'd say more than 50% of the HO scene art gave off "we have HO scene art at home, though" vibes. To be honest it just makes me grateful for how far Artifex Mundi has come on their HO scenes and their art in general.
The animation also isn't any exception to the "unintentionally funny" title. You really wouldn't think you'd be laughing much while the characters are having a Serious(TM) conversation about your father's kidnapping, but the way the faces wobble about because of the awkward (attempt at) animation really gave me a good chuckle - especially seeing as it wasn't particularly in sync with the voice over. Honestly creepy enough it could be used for a great horror HOG... And, again, I'm so deeply grateful for how far A.M. has come!

All in all, I'd give this game a 3.5/10, especially compared to many of A.M.'s other games. Still, if it's on sale, and you enjoy HOGs in general, [i]and[/i] you have a spare ~3 hours, might as well give it a whirl.

And if you don't take a liking to it, you can always stick it back into the hell-blender it came from.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076061891', 'num_games_owned': 3109, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1684085847}
review: This is a bad hidden object game. Artifex Mundi have made some pretty good games, but this early attempt fails on every level. Awful graphics where it's sometimes impossible to know what you are looking at and jaring animations on faces when they speak, Terrible voice acting, lackluster puzzles.... avoid at all cost.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122258825', 'num_games_owned': 3711, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1683941724}
review:
[list][*][b][h1]Morlan's shorts:[/h1][/b][/list]
Broken game.. If you are one of those players that detest skipping mini-games, do not play or buy this. It comes to a point of a mini-game that because people figured out the solution, they introduced a random number generator (the rune lights-on/off game) that makes the game unsolvable.
And frankly the rest of the game is not much to look at or play with.. Doesn't help that the HOG parts have some really small pieces that you pixel hunt for.. 
Nope, skip this..

[b]Don't waste more time reading lengthy reviews.. time is of the essence![/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197974462758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1461, 'last_played': 1702769738}
review: the best hidden object, puzzle and a good story too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063878029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1683526597}
review: I generally like the games of Artifex Mundi but in this game nothing is above average. The facial animations are awful, the story does not make anything out of the setting (only two screens per time period) and the time machine section is repetitive. The HO scenes are hard to capture and the choice of changing light in these scenes is just bad game design. It is not a totally bad game, but there is much better to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024767429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 157, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1683006669}
review:
Remastered my a__
The HOG scenes are basically blown up low res images. Sometimes, even when a hint shows you exactly where an object is supposed to be, you just don't see it... just click the area and get through it.

Story and voice acting aren't great either.

How they can charge $10 for this game I have no idea; I got it on deep sale and still feel jipped - spend your money on another HOG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042771493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1679025524}
review:
I really, really did not like this game. Let me try to articulate why.

First, there is a lot I like about it also. There are a lot of dialog scenes in the game, far more than most I have played, and I did enjoy that. The animations were a little janky since these early games mostly transform 2D shapes for animating things like talking as opposed to actually drawing all the frames, but it has a classic PC-CDROM charm to it.

This game had some of my favorite non-hidden object puzzles in a long time too. Some of them I just liked and didn't mind that they've been used in other games, but some were completely new to me and it had me wondering why I hadn't seen them used since in other games.

Lastly, speaking of puzzles, if the hidden object part of these games are your favorite puzzles, there are a TON of them in this game, more than in any other one of these games I've tried by a very wide margin.

But this is part of the issue for me. Because the game is older, a lot of the textures lacked the kind of detail you need to find these hidden objects properly, even with the remastering. But that aside, I also didn't really enjoy the puzzles and object locations at all. I know that all of these games attempt to hide or disguise the objects to a degree, but a lot of these were ridiculous and seemed to be hidden extremely aggressively on purpose. Typically, the objects stand out in some way or another, but these were mostly mundane things hidden among even more everyday objects. Some were named wrong, like a "candle" actually being just a candlestick.

The story also was mostly OK, except an important event at the end of the game isn't even revealed. I'll try to avoid spoilers, but the game ends very quickly in a nonsensical way, and doesn't explain or even reveal what this major catastrophe is that the game is building towards and is supposedly the crux of why the events of the game play out. Maybe trying to set up for a sequel, but regardless, this was not appreciated.

There is also one unmissable instance of part of the voice actor's dialog being said by a Microsoft Sam-type generated voice-- it's unclear if this was in the original, I assume strongly that it's part of the remaster and something they had to do because the original voice actor wasn't available anymore when the remaster was done, but it's just so noticeable and egregious. They try to add more exposition with it, which the game desperately needs, but it doesn't succeed, and so it's very jarring for no payoff.

The concept of the game and story was honestly fine, but because of the issues with it, I really wouldn't recommend it, there are better games you can play instead.

I did not encounter any technical issues while playing this game, and there is no bonus adventure. There are no collectibles, so you should at least be able to get all the achievements in one playthrough, although that "finish any hidden object puzzle in 1 minute or less" was brutal with the kinds of hidden object puzzles this game has.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203121399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 383, 'last_played': 1683850019}

Los dibujos estÃ¡n bien, no son wow, pero el carisma de su protagonista y su acento dan una jugabilidad amena. Lo recomiendo para pasar el rato o conocer la historia de la familia Ambrose. Yo por el momento me irÃ© a probar sus secuelas. Artifex no decepciona.

author: {'steamid': '76561198310863968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1673853652}
review: He jugado muchos juegos de Artifex, pero este sin duda ha sido el peor de todos, la historia carece de sentido, es repetitivo y ni hablar de los supuestos graficos remasterizados, ya que al final del juego te vas a encontrar con escenarios y puzzles borrosos. Definitivamente no recomendado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107461637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1673552168}
review: I expect so much more from Artifex Mundi. Yes, I know the game is older, but geeze man, the HOG's are so hard to see. The voice acting, the same voices as usual, was awful this time. This is one of my very least favorite of all of my many, I belonged to Big Fish for years, Hidden Object Games. Now that i completed the game I am going to go cry in my coffee having purchased this game instead of a different one.

review: A fun and simple hidden objects game. Though I will say for one there is a hidden objects puzzle you have to before every level in the same area where the light gets brighter than darker repeatedly while doing the puzzle. I can make it hard to see some of the objects and can possible make people feel dizzy/nausea...so if you are prone to such I wouldn't recommend this game for you. Another is this game had one of the harder puzzles I had to figure out (7th century witch's hut), don't know why I had such difficulty since once you figure it out it was easy â”(ï¿£ãƒ˜ï¿£)â”Œ

author: {'steamid': '76561198055205614', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1672164184}
review:
Quite old and repetitive HOG game, better keep to more recent Artifex Mundi games in my opinion.

Edit: I just played the second one in the series, and it's much better, so I recommend to skip this one and go straight to the next one. It won't be a problem storywise as you're not playing as the same character as in this opus.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015850375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1670295544}
review:
A reminder of where HOGs started, but oof, it was a bit rough to play through.

When you're in the time chamber looking for artifacts for the next portal, the light is flashing constantly, which was really annoying.

Definitely only recommend if you like hard HOGs and can tolerate outdated graphics and flashing lights. (And if you pick it up on sale.)

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198036297204', 'num_games_owned': 1295, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1626558625}
review:
Vivien is visiting her father, when he suddenly disappears into thin air. In a moment she learns that her family, Ambrose family, is full of magicians, scientists and most importantly time travelers. When searching for clues of father's whereabouts, she finds a mysterious talking crystal ball and seven magic rings, which then teleports her into the Time Museum. Sadly she collides with the abductor and the rings get lost. She has to visit different time epochs and find family rings which will then help her to track her father down. Who is the mysterious abductor and what does he want with the Ambrose family? Travel through time and space to find the ultimate answer.

From the first glance you can tell that it's an older game. It reminds me a lot of old point and click adventures, it has a similar vibe as [i]Atlantis[/i] (one of my favorite games by the way) for example. Graphics are older, but full of details and colorful. Character animation offers great laughs as their heads are so strangely moving during speaking. Gameplay wise there are a lot of hidden object scenes with a lot of items in them. Also there was usually some flashing light or something like that which made the searching a little harder. Puzzles were good.
Only complaint I have is for the UI design. I am now familiar with the concept that on the left side you have a menu with a diary and on the right side you have a hint. Here it is swapped so I had to control my urge to click it when quitting the game as I would hit the hint and would lose my achievement. ;)

You can't quite compare it to the newer Artifex Mundi games as it's of course older, more rough and maybe even simpler. But I have a weak spot towards those kinds of games and in the end I had a good time with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198872224217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1656830096}
review: An oldie that focuses almost solely on HO scenes. What little inventory there is is easy to find and there are a few "Find the difference" thrown in for good measure. The art is rough and the story is pretty basic, but otherwise a good little game. It would have been nice if the HOs actually were in league with the time you're supposed to be visiting, but it's a nitpick. As long as you don't skip any games or use any hints, it's an easy ride to 100%.

author: {'steamid': '76561198164016063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 333, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1651504237}
review:
pros

+ decent story about magical rings and time travel
+ you can go to different eras in history via time travel
+ nice variety background musics
+ voice acting ok for an ho game
+ two difficulty options
+ easy to solve fun mini games and puzzles
+ there are steam achievements

cons

- outdated and blurry graphics
- gameplay progress overstuffed with repetitive ho scenes and puzzles. there are more than necessary ho scenes
- there are some trial and error puzzles
- stiff character animations and weird face expressions
- game is short
- there is no bonus chapter
- no cards

Overall, this is an quite average ho game but it can be buy when it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971284198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1650098122}
review:
xD That story was a bit of fun...

Anyways, this is among the earlier Artifex Mundi games, it likely won't please fans of the newest games much.
Story is a bit wacky as it is for the earlier games, which is kinda funny in it's own way.

As for mechanics... there is a whole lot of focus on hidden object parts, and as an earlier game, it has the usual problems - low res photos, wonky scaling, some objects that are very hard to see due to the low image quality, weird lighting, a few misnamed objects, hidden object scenes that apparently have multiple items that matches names but only one is the right one.
There are also a few puzzles, one that got me so fed up that I had to skip. Nothing particularly wrong with it, it's just a type of puzzle that gets to my nerves super fast... first time seeing it in an Artifex Mundi game though.

But despite being short, even then there was a bit of economy on the number of different scenes side.
You basically pass through a time portal alternate dimension multiple times over, and each time you will search for objects in the same exact room, and go through a "find the differences" puzzle type thing multiple times. They are of course different each time, but it's still the same room and mechanic.

Getting closer to the end of the story the hidden object part ramp up considerably. Oh, despite being remastered, this one also has no bonus game... not a problem, but just so you know.

Again, I personally like playing the earlier games because I like to see how the genre evolved over the years for Artifex Mundi, but if you are more of a fan of the newer titles, be aware that it can be pretty crude in comparison. If you don't mind though, I do recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132503739', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 548, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1643822316}
review:
[b]Playing status:[/b] 100% achievement, finished the game
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (9 achievement).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Time Mysteries: Inheritance - Remastered[/b] is a hidden object game where you have to find 7 rings to save your father. The game has a lot of hidden object minigames compared to other [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/developer/artifexmundi]Artifex Mundi[/url][/i] games in general with harder difficulty.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 2 difficulties
- Some objects in hidden object scenes are tricky to find

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Progression is too redundant
- Sometimes it is hard to know how puzzles work at first glance

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]No.[/b]
[i]The game has aged too much to enjoy to its fullest. There are better Artifex Mundi games that you can buy at the same asking price.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
As I said before, the visuals have aged. Characters look weird whenever they are moving since the game tends to stretch the image in an awkward angle to simulate their movement. Moreover, the 3D backgrounds are too plain to see. The game still looks great in the hidden object scenes though since they are drawn in 2D, albeit a bit blurred.

[h3]Story[/h3]
To be honest, I didn't pay much attention to the story. My focus was shifted to the awkward movement that the character does from time to time, which is too funny to ignore. All dialogues revolve around the main objective that is given at the beginning although there will also be other tasks that await you in order to collect 7 rings that are needed to finish the game.

The story can feel confusing due to the time travel. You will have a new task whenever you time travel to a new era, although the game tends to skip introductions whenever the character arrives for the first time. New characters will appear out of nowhere and the main character will act as if she already knew that character for a long time.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=453019367 

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
The game is a combination of hidden objects, find 7 differences, and puzzles, with the hidden object minigame as the main focus. However, the gameplay loop is too repetitive with you having to do a combination of those 7 times before you finish the game. Moreover, there wasn't much break time between the hidden object scenes. It was exhausting to have another hidden object scene right after I finished the previous one.

The hidden object's gameplay is similar to other [i]Artifex Mundi[/i] games in general with you having to find objects from the given words. There aren't many words that are too confusing in this game, although objects tend to be hidden in a way that makes them hard to find. I admit that I had difficulties finding some of them - I even had to take a break from time to time to shift my focus for it.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=399841610 

It's hard to know how puzzles work at first glance. There might be an instruction on how to finish them, but I didn't notice that the button exist until halfway in the game. Moreover, the puzzle looks simple enough to solve at first - it's just that it's unclear as to what I should do to figure out the solution. Take the Hanoi Tower puzzle for example. I wasn't sure whether I should build the tower on the left, middle, or right side. The hints that are given without looking at the instruction are not obvious enough to notice.

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the game in 3h in the easiest difficulty, although it can be finished shorter depending on your skill. It took me some time to finish the hidden objects and find 7 differences minigames since I wasn't sharp enough to find the objects. If you don't want to play the hidden object minigames, you can switch it with match-3 minigames, although I didn't use it much due to the achievements that require me to finish the game by clearing the hidden object minigames. The game also offers a hint button if you need it, which again, can't be used for achievement hunters due to the achievement constraint.

As for the puzzles, most of them are easy enough if you know what to do, but I had difficulty with one puzzle. Luckily, there is a skip button for those who don't care about achievements.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1659827965 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Time Mysteries: Inheritance - Remastered[/b] is a solid hidden object game that has poorly aged. Despite the good British voiceover, the story looks like a joke with the animations, which I was too focused on due to its weirdness. Moreover, the story itself can be confusing with new characters and plots that are appearing from a new timeline, and the new plot won't be relevant after you shifted to another timeline. Since there are better [i]Artifex Mundi[/i] games that you can buy at the same price, I couldn't recommend this game, although those who like hidden object minigames could still give the game a try since the quality was better than the newer [i]Artifex Mundi[/i] games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072113884', 'num_games_owned': 877, 'num_reviews': 222, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1640742701}
review:
All of us who play HoG's know that the skill of the entire industry with voice acting and animation is shoddy at best. This game sets a new low standard. It's pretty easy to get good reviews on these games. Have pretty backgrounds. Make objects hidden. Make a mediocre ridiculous story, all done! And we play them that way because they're fun! 

Understand, I'm taking into account that this game is older... But that's no excuse. The animation and voice acting is the worst I've ever seen. The resolution is very poor. Even the hidden object puzzles have poor res. Just skip it. There's nothing here worth your time when there's so many other offerings. 

+ The achievements work. Woohoo. 

+/- Music is fine. Nothing great. It's repetitive, but it's not terrible. 

- Animation
- Voice acting
- Graphics in general

author: {'steamid': '76561198392429301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1640525181}
review:
DON'T BUY IT! 

This game is not worthy enough for its original cost, unless you but it in a bundle or discount. The drawings of the background and objects were pretty, but the drawings of the human characters, and the voice cover is SOOOO weird. 

Comparing to other games posted by Artifex Mundi, this is one of the worst I would say. The story is nonsense, it just gives random quest for a very simple reason. And when the characters talk, you can see that the whole face of the character is moving, not mentioning that the main character's face cannot even be seen clearly. 

I understand that this is actually published a really long time ago, and is not as qualified as the ones posted in near times, but still, this is not a good game in both the game play, the game view, and the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198845717264', 'num_games_owned': 366, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1640505565}
review:
Thumbs down! This is rather disappointing for Artifex Mundi. Theyâ€™ve had much better hidden object games. This game was originally released in 2010, but the remastered version was released in 2014. I was able to run this okay under Windows 10 and get all the achievements, so I guess that the remaster might have helped with bugs and glitches. However, I disliked certain aspects of the game itself.

Several hidden object scenes have a flickering light that makes objects hard to see. I found that to be more annoying than challenging. Iâ€™m not a big fan of spot-the-difference puzzles, but there were about a half dozen of them. The animation did not look natural when the characters were talking. They would have been better off with still portraits than whatever weird technique they used.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077581468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1638134556}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028711579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 284, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1636752851}
review:
Well... Having played close to the entire Artifex Mundi catalouge of HOG's, I can safely say this has been the worst.

Apart from some unintentionally funny "animations" (dragging the mouth around on a still frame for example) and voice acting (once a character even is text-to-speech all of a sudden, probably because they needed added dialouge when the actor was no longer availible) this game commits the absolute worst of sins, namely being dull. I mean, a silly, childish or stupid story with plotholes, contrived coincidences and unclear motivations can be very entertaining. Especially if it got nice colors and art and fun, if even familiar, relaxing puzzles. But this is actually boring. It's also ugly to look at, and the HO scenes are low res, which makes them somewhat frustrating.

Easy 100% achievements though. And, for perspective, it can be interesting to see how far we've come in the genre.

But I would still recommend to skip it. I bought it on sale for 6 euro, and it was still too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062678111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1641002012}
review:
This game has a lot of potential to be great.  A woman travels to different eras in time to find lost rings she inherited from her father.  I don't want to give away any surprises, but that's the basic story.  

Improvements need to be made in the graphics for hidden object scenes. They tend to be a bit blurred. Some items were invisible (too opaqued), some were stretched a bit out of aspect ratio.  The room you go to in the museum to find objects to take for the next era was masked with a white layer and blurred, probably to give it an other-worldly feel.  Many objects sat on shelves in the back and sides and were too tiny to see well.

You follow a regular rhythm of hidden object scenes, find the differences, and time traveling.  So there are many HO scenes.  

I would love to see the story filled out and the graphics for the HO scenes improved.  The ending seemed a bit abrupt.  Still, I would like to see a sequel, and hope that growth and improvement come with time.

author: {'steamid': '76561199161487173', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1632875504}
review:
This game does not display very well in Full HD (1920x1080), 
all the illustrations of the hidden objects games are blurry and noisy/pixelated.

Gameplay is rather slow and quite boring. So is the background music. 

I am a fan of HOG games and this one is far from being successful or attractive. 
Graphisms are poorly rendered and overall theme looks old. 

I quit after only a couple of hours.

I recommand games like  "Dracula Love Kills"  or  "Grim Legends" series. 

Do not waist your time, you've been warned.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970310850', 'num_games_owned': 335, 'num_reviews': 257, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1630262931}
review:
[b]5/10[/b]

[h1]Unteres Ende des Wimmelbild-Spektrums[/h1]

Time Mysteries ist im Original von 2010 und das merkt man, trotz des Remasters von 2014. Es unterbietet auf mehreren Ebenen die niedrigen Erwartungen, die man an diese Art von Spielen eh schon hat. Es sei gleich mal dazugesagt, dass HOPAs mein Guilty Pleasure sind und ich nicht nur allgemein, sondern auch speziell in diesem Genre kein sehr kritischer Spieler bin - was z.B. Story oder Grafik betrifft. In diesem Fall, obwohl ich mich auf (m)eine Art unterhalten fÃ¼hlte, stelle ich objektive Argumente Ã¼ber mein persÃ¶nliches Empfinden und rate von dem Spiel ab - zumindest zum "Vollpreis".

[h1]Technik[/h1]

TM lÃ¤uft natÃ¼rlich wie ein Ã¼bliches Wimmelbildspiel ab: man wechselt von Szene zu Szene, sammelt InventargegenstÃ¤nde, lÃ¶st Minispiele, und lÃ¤sst seine Augen durch Wimmelbilder kreisen. Das funktioniert auch alles gut. Das grafische Manko ist, dass das Spiel gefÃ¼hlt nicht oder nicht konsequent auf 16:9 umgestellt wurde (erscheint mir teilweise gestreckt) und v.a. die Wimmelbilder nicht auf HD aktualisiert wurden. Dadurch, dass sie in dieser Ã„ra (um 2010 oder frÃ¼her noch) sehr filigran waren, wird die Sache doch sehr erschwert.
Nicht zu vergessen wÃ¤re es, dass Charaktere jetzt, vermutlich als Upgrade zum Original, in den Cutscenes "sprechen": die starren Figuren wurden in Sprache und Mimik rudimentÃ¤r animiert, indem man ihnen die entsprechenden Teile verzerrt hat. Das ist mit diesem einfachen Mittel teils und den UmstÃ¤nden entsprechend erstaunlich gut gelungen, andererseits sehen nun die meisten Charaktere aus wie BlubberkÃ¶ppe: nicht nur Mund oder Augenpartie werden bewegt, es wabert der ganze Kopf. Unfreiwillig komisch.
Die Musik empfand ich insgesamt als mÃ¤ÃŸig, da ich auf Dauer nicht auf mittelalterliches Geklimper und Gezupfe stehe.
Die sprachliche Vertonung ist bis auf eine Figur in Ordnung. Der Zeitreisende ist eher ein Laie bei der Lokalisierung, spricht aber auch nur zum Ende was und auch nicht viel.

[h1]RÃ¤tsel[/h1]

Es gibt viele Wimmelbildszenen, das ist grundsÃ¤tzlich gut. Aber einiges konnte ich daran auch nicht so gut genieÃŸen.
1. Sie sind teilweise pulsierend mit Licht durchflutet, was eher nervt
2. Das Museum der Zeit muss man immer wieder durchqueren - nicht mein Lieblings(wimmel)raum
3. Objekte sind teilweise in Form UND Farbe super deckend angepasst, oder so hinter anderen Objekten versteckt, dass man wenig Chancen hat, irgendwelche markanten Umrisse Ã¼berhaupt nur zu entdecken.
4. zu den Ã¼blichen Ãœbersetzungsfehlern kommen auch noch unklare Bezeichnungen, z.b. ein Kerzenhalter ohne(!) Kerze, der aber als Kerze gesucht ist...

Ãœberraschenderweise haben die Wimmelbilder am Ende an Gemeinheit verloren und waren plÃ¶tzlich (zu) einfach. Nur warum fehlte hier die Konsequenz? Entweder das Eine oder das Andere, besser noch ein Mittelding, das wÃ¤re meins gewesen.

Die Minispiele sind fast allesamt nicht schwer zu lÃ¶sen, trotzdem wÃ¤re es fair, wenn es bequemerweise eine kleine ErklÃ¤rung gÃ¤be, wie (nach welcher Logik) sie funktionieren bzw. was das Ziel ist. Das habe ich zumindest bisher in allen anderen Wimmelbildspielen so gesehen.

Weitestgehend logisch ist aber zumindest alles. Weil jedes Zeitalter nur wenig Raum/RÃ¤ume bietet, sind die "adventurigen" Verwicklungen, das Hantieren mit dem Inventar, nicht allzu arg.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Geht ohne groÃŸe Umschweife, aber leider auch sehr undetailliert vonstatten. Ehe man sich's versieht, reist man durch die Jahrhunderte, man kommt thematisch Ã¼berhaupt nicht richtig rein. Physikerin, Kristallkugel, Zeitreiseapparat zum Aktivieren und ruckzuck werden die Jahrhunderte abgeklappert. Der PlausibilitÃ¤t des Ganzen hÃ¤tte es nicht geschadet, wenn man da etwas mehr MÃ¼he in die ganzen ZusammenhÃ¤nge gesteckt hÃ¤tte. Hauptcharakter Vivian wird in egal welcher Zeit stets so empfangen, als wÃ¤re das ganz normal, und sofort steht fest, was zu tun ist. Zudem lÃ¤uft alles sehr linear ab: so lange RÃ¤tsel lÃ¶sen, bis man in den Besitz eines der sieben fehlenden Ringe gerÃ¤t, zurÃ¼ck ins Museum der Zeit, Ring einsetzen, kurzes "finde die Unterschiede"-RÃ¤tsel lÃ¶sen, neue GegenstÃ¤nde fÃ¼r das nÃ¤chste Jahrhundert zusammenwimmeln und ab geht's wieder zurÃ¼ck in der Zeit.
Der Begleiter an der Seite des Spielers ist eine sprechende Zauberkugel. Schon recht albern. Nicht dass das Spiel diese Albernheit nicht sogar wollen wÃ¼rde, aber das trÃ¤gt nicht zur GlaubwÃ¼rdigkeit der Story bei.
Irgendwie kam ich atmosphÃ¤risch auch Ã¼berhaupt nicht in die Geschichte rein. Jedes Zeitalter besteht aus 2-3 Szenen und es kommt wenig GefÃ¼hl fÃ¼r das Setting auf. Nirgendwo findet man sich ein, man springt nur stÃ¤ndig von hierhin nach dorthin und schon ist die nÃ¤chste Epoche ohne groÃŸe Nachwirkungen abgehakt.
Leider ist inhaltlich nur ein kleiner Twist drin - den man allerdings ahnen konnte.
Als Trilogie bleibt wenigstens das Ende offen und lÃ¤dt zum nÃ¤chsten Teil ein.
PersÃ¶nliche Note: ich hÃ¤tte beim Thema Zeitreisen gerne ein wenig mehr Sci-Fi Thematik drin gehabt, aber es lÃ¤uft Artifex-typisch wieder auf ÃœbernatÃ¼rliches/Magie hinaus. Leider geht's auch hauptsÃ¤chlich ins zweite Jahrtausend. FÃ¼r die folgenden Teile wÃ¼rde ich mir ja mal einen Blick in die Zukunft wÃ¼nschen - oder meinetwegen auch den in eine ganz ferne Vergangenheit.

Fazit:

[h1]Leider nicht mehr zeitgemÃ¤ÃŸ (pun intended)[/h1]

Zum VervollstÃ¤ndigen und im Sale sollte es allerdings fÃ¼r HOPA-Fans kein Fehler sein.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989955975', 'num_games_owned': 897, 'num_reviews': 402, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1630095767}
review: A bit dated.  The facial "animations" are atrocious - all are animated painted scenes.  The story is decent; the dialogue is bit lame, but the voice acting is good enough.  There are many HO scenes and several puzzles, so those parts are good.  Overall, good enough for a thumbs up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198191967215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1626008031}
review: Listen, okay, I do actually enjoy these dumb Hidden Object games every now and then, but this one just bored the hell out of me. It felt overwhelmingly boring and repetitive. And then suddenly the voice acting, which is almost always terrible in these games, and the weird face distortion to pretend motion/speaking just... become too much. I actually rushed through the last 2h without sound and just skipping through all the """"story"""".

author: {'steamid': '76561198106507444', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1625283562}
review: Was excited about this trilogy of games from Artifex because they make pretty good casual games. Unfortunately, they did this one on the cheap. The HO puzzles are poorly done and remind me of the Art of Murder HO games where they just use existing photographs, which make it difficult to tell what things are in the picture. They also just used pictures of people and made their mouths move. And this is the remastered version? I can't imagine what the original looked like if this one looks this bad. The whole thing just looked really cheap. Too bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087874412', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1624844669}
review:
Primitive and dated. Presumably, "Remastered" only refers to the cut-scene graphics, as the actual HOG sections are comically easy. You can find well over half the hidden objects simply by clicking on the stuff that stands out from the rest of the image.

Also, the achievements are limited and can be gotten in a single playthrough. There's not hidden items to find, you don't even need to play on expert mode, which makes finishing this game with all achievements ridiculously simple.

I skipped most of the story because, frankly, there was no achievement to watch all cut scenes. And these games aren't known for great stories anyway.

Gameplay consists of solving a HOG for an item which transports you to a specific period of time. Within these periods of time there's only 2 or 3 scenes, a few more HOGs, and at least one instructionless mini-game. There's about 8 or 9 of these time periods and they're easily solvable if you haven't slept in 3 days, as they only require about .45% of you brain's attention.  There's a good chance that a small child just randomly clicking the mouse around the screen could complete this game. And sometimes randomly clicking the mouse around the screen is the best way to solve the HOGs or minigames.

Overall, even if you're a huge HOG fan, stay away from this one unless you just want a simple game to add to your "100%" list.

author: {'steamid': '76561199095484177', 'num_games_owned': 859, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1620415215}
review:
unintentionally quite funny, characters move like they're in a slideshow and the voice-acting is so cheesy it's unreal.
But a relatively strong older AM title, even if it's outdated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060034265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1620061663}
review:
This is an "old-fashioned" Hidden Object Game (HOG). Old fashioned, as in very hard HOG scenes. Some of those contain very tiny objects or poor color choice that make object very hard to distinguish.

Still, there are many HOG scenes, quite a few puzzles - without any indication whatsoever regarding what's expected ! - and some "find-the-difference" between two pics throughout chapters of the game.

Despite the aged graphics and the difficulty, it's still my kind of game. It takes about 3 to 4 hours to complete a run. Several were needed, for me, to trigger all the achievements.

It ran fine on a Win7 64bit box

author: {'steamid': '76561198035385754', 'num_games_owned': 1385, 'num_reviews': 492, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1619432282}
review:
This was painful to complete. Atleast it was easy to get hints or even skip the puzzles.

The game is just not living up to "todays standards". Some puzzle pictures are poor graphic wise, leaving the objects showing too easily as they stand out, while other pictures are too pixly that you barely can't find the items. 
My eyes hurt lol.

On top of that the characters are hilarious, both voice acting vice and graphic wise. 
Atleast the game gave me few laughs.

author: {'steamid': '76561199140041023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1616781597}
review: Hidden object puzzles are a lot harder than usual AM games so if you like that aspect the best this is the game for you. The other puzzles are so-so and revolve mostly around "switches" where pressing a button changes the state of the buttons next to it etc. I found these a bit frustrating at times. The artwork isn't as impressive as other AM games but I think this is an older title so they've come along way since then.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081253471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1616705517}
review: This game has a little more on hidden objects and the puzzles didn't provide information what you need to do to solve.  Basically you are jumping from one time period to another and each time period has 2-3 screens.  You have to solve one time period before you can jump to another.  There are also some puzzles and find the difference between 2 pictures.  Puzzles are easy to be solved.  I am not sure I understand the story.  Nothing is difficult to solve on this game.  There is no extra story to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144392599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1616078131}
review: It's an Artifex Mundi game, so you know what to expect. I have almost all of them. There's not many that I'd not recommend. Maybe this one is a bit older, but it's image quality alone that makes this one a bit difficult at times. Some of the scenes seem stretched, which is off-putting. Most are hazy and unclear. The colours tend to be a bit flat, too, but I actually think that that would be fine - objects tend to blend in better - only with the low quality it makes it extra difficult. Not that this one is overly difficult. I found it got too easy by the end. The story is a bit dorky. Actually, my favourite part of this game was probably the creativity employed in animating the hand-drawn still images to make the cut-scenes. That and a few of the songs. Very nice music in this one, actually. Not terrible. Not great. Just the image quality that ruined it for me. Can't really do anything about that, but there's so many others to choose from that I could only recommend this if you want it to complete the collection, just collect HOGs in general, or want some nice music. Otherwise, I'd say pass on this one. There's much better to choose from for better prices.

author: {'steamid': '76561199112640976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1615653940}
review: Cool story. Very short game, could've finished in a day if I had played it continuously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198929512897', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1625945272}
review:
The hidden object scenes have the same objects again and again. I had to search for gloves so many times.
Not only it's boring, but there's a horrible sun light into the scenes that keeps shining "on/off" and honestly it bothers me a lot when searching for the objects. 
Game is short, story is somewhat nice, overall: very boring and there's the annoying light, repetitive scenes and objects.
Definitely not recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154273655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1615059448}
review:
So, it's not great. 
But it's not absolutely horrendous! 
It's OK if you want something simple (not saying it's super easy but I got through most of it pretty quick,) and you don't mind bad voice acting and not very good animating. The artwork itself looks good, but in some of the HOPs (hidden object puzzles) the picture is very blurry and ups the difficulty - which I don't think it's supposed to do. 
Now I understand this is an older game of Artifex Mundi, so I can live with bad graphics and a short and weird storyline, but all in all I enjoyed it. 
If you like these developers and their games (I've played a few and love themâ™¥) I'd say pick this up on sale! But only if you feel like it. It's not highly recommended, but it's not awful. It's OK.

review: I actually enjoyed this a lot more than I thought I would. The hidden object puzzles were really fun to do and it required you to go to different areas to finish the puzzles and go to the next area. The music was pretty nice and set the tone in certain stages. This game didn't have any bugs, loading or saving issues. The achievements are also really easy and you can get most of them just by finishing the puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111115910', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1613151433}
review:
Let's put it bluntly this game just really isn't any good, even on sale.

The graphics are absolutely terrible and your eyes will hurt after playing because of the low resolution of the hidden object scenes. Also you can sometimes guess which items have been put in the scenes without having to read what items you need because of the difference in image resolution between the items and the scene.
The story is laughable and repetitive, the ending is so bad it feels like a spit in the face after a very uncomfortable golden shower. The diaolgues and voice acting are pretty bad too.
The "mini-games" are maybe my biggest gripe with the games, always the same unoriginal and soul crushing stuff (I hope you like spot the differences), some are not even games : two of them literally require you to click the correct stuff multiple times in a row.
I honestly think the animations were an inspiration for Mosi Masahiro in identifying the uncanny valley.

Don't buy it.

review:
not a bad hidden object game but one of the biggest problems I had with this game was that its hidden object puzzles were a bit on the blurry side which made solving them quite a bit more trouble than I think it really should have. I also didn't care for the way they chose to animate the characters faces and mouths it was really odd looking and I believe I would have liked it better if they hadn't tried to make it look like they were moving. 
I believe that there are better hidden object games out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981557797', 'num_games_owned': 5239, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1612121294}
review: This is a soft recommend.  There are better hidden object games out there; but it was just entertaining enough to finish.  The voice acting and cut scenes are awful. There's a strange pulsing/pulling effect that they put on the characters faces whenever they're supposed to be talking.  This in combination with the incredibly poor voice acting is groan inducing.  Also, many of the hidden object scenes have a pulsing light effect that can be distracting.  Finally, the story itself is kind of a mess and the wrap up of the story felt really choppy from a storytelling and delivery perspective.  It's not great; but if you enjoy this genre you'll probably get just enough enjoyment out of it to make the approximately 3 hour experience worthwhile.

review:

Not my cup of tea, I'd rather play Enigmatis or Grim Legends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096798660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1609823523}

author: {'steamid': '76561197965585057', 'num_games_owned': 888, 'num_reviews': 224, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1608774615}
review:
So, I like modern hidden picture games. There just isn't enough here. The puzzles are incredibly simple. The hidden object screens often have items that... it's hard to describe, are just rendered poorly to the point of just being unfun? Again, not a difficulty issue rather than a graphical one. The story is basically non-existent. The writing is weak. The voice acting is pretty flat, and the animations are terrifying. They do this weird stretching effect to move people's mouths that ends up being a little disturbing? They actually would have been better off with no animations at all, and it would have been cheaper for them to do.

Overall, you're better off giving this one a pass and picking up one of the later Midnight Mystery games if you're into this genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044715770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1609188996}
review: Possibly the worst AM game I've played. Creepy uncanny-valley character animations. LOTS of hidden-object puzzles, but many are reused scenes and there are inconsistencies between object descriptions (what's a candle, the wax cylinder or the base or both? why isn't the "upside down airplane" stamp considered a stamp?), plus some "just the nose of the object is showing" issues. Gameplay is super-clunky and it isn't always clear or even logical what you should do next. Puzzles often don't have instructions, and there are several puzzle-type repetitions. Music is often annoying. Just a sloppy, unprofessional game overall, and well below AM's standards. Even as a "remaster", it kind of sucks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996273719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 798, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1451914991}
review:
[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Time Mysteries: Inheritance - Remastered is a hidden object adventure developed by Artifex Mundi.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

When a windy time traveler kidnaps her father, Vivien has to look for them both in the past. A mysterious crystal ball accompanies you on a journey through time where you get to know Vivien's relatives. You have to collect seven seven magic rings in order to supply the crystal ball with energy. You solve puzzles, explore beautiful landscapes and solve one or the other mini-game.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ compelling story
+ partly challenging puzzles
+ solid graphic style
+ consistent sound
+ several levels of difficulty
+ Notebook
+ Help function
+ Trading cards and achievements

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- short playing time
- sometimes too easy

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Time Mysteries: Inheritance - Remastered offers you a compelling story, combined with good puzzles. Clear purchase recommendation for fans of this genre.


[h1] Information / Review Deutsch [/h1]

Time Mysteries: Inheritance - Remastered ist ein Wimmelbild-Abenteuer, welches von Artifex Mundi entwickelt wurde.

[h1] Gameplay / Geschichte [/h1]

Als ein windiger Zeitreisender ihren Vater entfÃ¼hrt, muss Vivien die beiden in der Vergangenheit suchen. Eine geheimnisvolle Kristallkugel begleitet Dich auf einer Zeitreise, bei der Du Viviens Verwandtschaft kennenlernst. Du musst sieben sieben magische Ringe sammeln, um die Kristallkugel mit Energie zu versorgen. Dabei lÃ¶st du RÃ¤tsel, erkundest wunderschÃ¶ne Landschaften und lÃ¶st das ein oder andere Minispiel.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ fesselnde Geschichte
+ teils anspruchsvolle RÃ¤tsel 
+ solider Grafikstil 
+ stimmiger Sound
+ mehrere Schwierigkeitsgrade
+ Notizbuch
+ Hilfefunktion
+ Sammelkarten und Errungenschaften

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

- kurze Spielzeit 
- teils zu einfach

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Time Mysteries: Inheritance - Remastered bietet dir eine fesselnde Geschichte, kombiniert mit guten RÃ¤tsel. Klare Kaufempfehlung fÃ¼r Fans dieses Genres.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971880699', 'num_games_owned': 2849, 'num_reviews': 419, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1600764835}
review:
Duration: Steam says 2.8 hours, I thought it was less, but I may have fallen asleep. 

Strobing lights during HO scenes - check!
Travel to 7 different ages, each with two areas to explore!
No interactive map, so you don't know which of the two areas to explore first, how exciting!
Real voice acting by 100% amateurs!
Test your wits, as there are no instructions for the mini-games!
Listen to the calming music of the bouzouki!

3/10. What can I say, I must be hard to please.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1609608699}
review:
This is a routine hidden object casual puzzle/adventure game with mild historical/fantasy/mystery theme. Solving various puzzles and hidden object minigames reveals the plot and uncovers the mystery.

Once more we see Artifex Mundi trying to screw over PC gamers. On Steam, this is $10 USD, on app stores, it's completely free. Mobile devs must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay a premium for a free mobile game just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064524511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1590126044}
review:
It was a good enough game, but honestly nowhere near the level of the subsequent two games (which I own through Big Fish Games).
I actually didn't know that this one existed until I stumbled across it by accident on Steam.  I thought 'Yay!  The others were amazing, so I know I'll like this one'.
Yeah.  Didn't live up to my expectations.  If you like HOGs and time travel, play the two sequels, especially the collector's editions, if you can get them.  This one was so unmemorable (is that a word?) that I can't remember whether there was anything that I liked about it.

review: I don't know what this was but it wasn't the usual quality experience I've got accustomed from Artifex Mundi. Story is weak and runs in loops, animations are sub par and the end is confusing, I guess forcing me to play a sequel? It's not a terrible game but not something I'd recommend to anyone looking for their first HOPA unless I want them to hate the genre, and for experienced "clickers"... um, well, it's playable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060520575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1593149790}
review:
This game is absolutely crazy. Everything about this game is done wrong, and done wrong in a way that is downright weird. I don't even know where to begin, but I'll just start by saying the way they animate people talking in this game is genuinely terrifying. I think actually make it look like the characters were talking was too hard or cost too much money or wasn't scary enough or something, so what they did instead is warp the entire character's head when they speak. The back of the head quivers and the forehead pulsates and all parts of the head are moving in different directions at once, and because of this it sort of looks like the mouth is moving. Think of any time you've seen someone talking. How much forehead pulsating did it involve? Your answer should be none, and the answer of any one who is a human and has seen other humans talk should be none. The way their faces move is so unsettling the only thing they should really be saying is "help me there is a human soul trapped in here free me free meeeeeeee". 

The voice acting is similarly weird. It is not just terrible, although it is terrible for sure. But there are weird stylistic choices that just baffle me. Here's a thing: I can't tell if one of the characters is a computer program or not. I don't mean that as a joke. He sounds like one of the text to speech programs you find online, and not a good one that can pass as human. I'm not sure if this is a person making themselves sound like this or if they just randomly picked one character to be voiced by some program they found online, but either way it is such a weird choice. Everyone else is human, I think, but are clearly not professional voice actors and might not even be people who routinely speak to other people. You could tell me the entire cast here lived in a cave their entire lives and had learned to speak two weeks before the game was made and Iâ€™d believe you. Everyone talks like they are reading a list of chemicals theyâ€™ve never heard of off the side of a bottle of shampoo and they emote like a calculator that was brought to life by a boring wizard. 

It is hard to get into the plot without "ruining" it (and I am using that sarcastically here because there is no way to ruin this plot) so I'll just try to summarize things and say it is really, really dumb. Our heroine is going home to visit her father, and she immediately knows something is up because she sees someone in the attic, a room that takes up roughly half the house and that her father had sealed up decades ago. Imagine if your father had sealed up an entire floor of your house and wouldn't let anyone go up there for decades. How unsurprised would you be when the FBI burst down your door and took away all your dadâ€™s puppets made of human remains? But whatever, because she turns out to be right. Her father is missing and in the attic she finds a letter talking about her â€œinheritanceâ€ which is a set of  MAGICAL TIME TRAVELING weird rings. Yes, thatâ€™s right, folks, her father was a secret time traveler and has run into some sort of trouble with someone who wanted his magical rings capable of time traveling. Vivien soon finds a magic, talking crystal ball that wants to help her find her father. This happens within the first five minutes of the game, and it only gets dumber from there.

There are plots that are bad because no one tried and plots that are bad because the writers accidentally ate a bad piece of fish and are now hallucinating, and I have no idea what is the case here. It is an all-around, cataclysmically bad execution of the story that I have to believe it is some mix of both. Vivien reacts to discovering her father is a time traveling wizard in possession of a talking crystal ball with all the surprise of someone who found potato chips in their bag of potato chips. The game is always desperate to get back to the hidden object scenes so it feels like the plot is on an all out sprint at all times. Characters are introduced and disappear two lines later and it feels like someone watched a re-cap of the story a week ago on Youtube and is now desperately trying to recount what little they remember of the plot from memory. . Major events in this game are just sort of glossed over and you reach the point where plotholes become so significant that the plot is more holes than actual plot. It is a nonsensical mess of absolutely insanity, and it feels like the end result of hitting the writers on top of the head with a mallet until enough words fell out of their mouths to make a plot.

I would have forgiven all of this is the game was actually fun to play, but it isn't. The hidden object scenes are terrible, and a lot of them have this werid light pulsating in the background that makes things harder to see. Some scenes have objects in the background that are straight up blurry which I thought might be because this was an older game, but then scenes l found later in the game were perfectly clear so I don't know what is going on. Objects can be ill defined or vague, and sometimes they just tell you to find the wrong thing. They want you to find a "pan flute" but they write out "flute" and these are two totally different things. It would be like if they wanted you to find "sand paper" and just wrote out "paper". The other puzzles in the game aren't much better, and almost all of them will solve themselves almost immediately. The most "difficult" puzzle in the game is a sliding block puzzle that will likely take you less than a minute to finish. Everything is just so easy and basic and you can tell they were really struggling to come up with good puzzle ideas.

I hated this game, but I almost want to recommend it to you anyway because of how weird it is. It is such a bizarre package of failure that you almost need to see it for yourself. This is to video games what Sharknado is to film and what that crazy homeless guy in the park yelling random lines of Othello to pigeons is to theater, and it so strange and so bad you feel this urge to show it to other people so they can celebrate its terribleness with you. This game is so bad its terrible and so bad its good at the same time, and I cannot stress how much you should avoid it and also somehow play it yourself at the same time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198325826628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1590304931}
review:
One of the worst Artifex Mundi games ever made. Hidden Object Puzzles are a torture because you often just cant see the objects due to really poor Graphics. A really cheap way to make HO puzzles more difficult. The most annoying and outraging thing in this game is that you have to do a HO in the same room like a hundred times..(Everytime you find a Ring) And whoever came up with the idea it would be great to have a flashing background in that room should be purged and forced to play this room forever!

Maybe the poor Graphics are just due to a bad port from mobile.. what makes it even more outrageous is them charging you  at least twice as much as they charge on the mobile for the same game.. ITS EXACTLY THE SAME GAME!!!!!! (low resolution pictures dont get better just by raising resolution... grrrr)

Better play The Room 1-3.  Really great games and Artifex Mundi could really step up to producing something great like Fireproof does instead of releasing the same mediocre, generic crap over and over in disguise..

author: {'steamid': '76561198073343336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1590135620}
review:
Some of the graphics are really bad. It's no fun to search hidden objects in blurred graphics.
I finished it anyway but it's totally outdated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052332539', 'num_games_owned': 976, 'num_reviews': 335, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1588194138}
review:
Im Vergleich zu anderen Spielen dieses Genres kann Time Mysteries: Inheritance leider nicht punkten. Eigentlich hÃ¤tte die Geschichte vom Inhalt her ja Potential, wurde aber sehr langweilig umgesetzt. Dies liegt auch daran, dass der Ablauf das ganze Spiel Ã¼ber der gleiche ist. Man startet die Maschine mit Hilfe eines "Fehlersuchspiels", findet dann fÃ¼r das jeweilige Jahrhundert, in das man reisen will, in einer immer mehr oder weniger gleichen Wimmelbildszene typische GegenstÃ¤nde aus dieser Zeit und betritt dann das andere Jahrhundert. Dort angekommen, besteht die Szenerie meist nur aus 1 oder 2 Stationen und schon geht es wieder zurÃ¼ck zur Maschine...

Mini-Spiele findet man nur wenige, meist bestehen die "RÃ¤tsel" aus Wimmelbildszenen. Diese sind wirklich sehr anstrengend, da sehr schlecht dargestellt und durch stÃ¶rende Lichteffekte nichts fÃ¼r schlechte Augen. Gut, das Spiel ist alt. Aber dafÃ¼r ist der Vollpreis noch ganz schÃ¶n happig. Wer es der VollstÃ¤ndigkeit halber spielen mÃ¶chte, um die Serie komplett zu haben, sollte unbedingt darauf warten, bis es im Sale zu haben ist. Ansonsten kann man das Spiel auch als HOG-Fan getrost auslassen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162415151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1583647308}
review:
I would only recommend this game to players who have played Artifex games before as a fun exercise of how far their gameplay has come. I had a fun time watching the goofy way the faces were animated and catching the glitches along the way. Events kind of just happen without fanfare, one of the characters sounds so robotic I honestly wondered if it was a text to speech voice at first, and most of the game is just puzzles with immediate solutions. For clarity on the last part, Artifex with their more recent games has a decent amount of breathing room in between puzzles, and the items you pick up aren't necessarily used in the nearby locations or right away. 

I wouldn't recommend this particular game for people new to this type of game in general or to Artifex Mundi games. I feel like it would just discourage you. I would much more recommend the Enigmatis or Nightmare series.
