author: {'steamid': '76561197984793828', 'num_games_owned': 2063, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1465700398}
review:
Just under 3 hours to get 100% achievements.

It is not *bad* per say, but they've done so much better titles since. Skip this one.

Couldn't care about the story, the tentative facial animations are atrocious, too much repetition. It even repeats "rush hour" type puzzles - yawn. Also no no hints/rule/goal to many mini game/puzzle sequences. Messy art style on HO scenes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116975671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1439902580}
review: While I my feelings for virtually all Artifex Mundi games tend to range between fondness and adoration, this game gets a failing grade. As the game is an older game, the art, gameplay mechanisms, writing and voice acting are expectedly subpar by AM's current standards; I would overlook those aspects except that I cannot imagine that I would've been impressed with them at the time it came out, either. The art is simply bad: unispired, not vibrant, and objects are hard to find because they are poorly illustrated, not to mention the recycling of the same scenes maybe a dozen times in some instances. The gameplay time switch mechanism is highly tedious; thankfully it is improved in subsequent games. And the writing and voice acting sucks, quite simply. What should be one of the most interesting concepts in AMs storyline canon is badly squandered here. The best thing about this game is the steam cards. [ 3 / 10 ]

author: {'steamid': '76561197965615203', 'num_games_owned': 2853, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1453574999}
review: Short, fun and unintentionally hilarious. Consider the dev's other titles, since this one is pretty dated... though I had a good chuckle or two at its expense. Might be worth picking up when it goes on a deep sale or if you've beaten literally every other Hidden Object game, since it is fun in its own right, but the genre has evolved a lot since this game's first outing and TM:I is more of a curiosity these days.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028216179', 'num_games_owned': 2423, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1439793015}
review:
NOTE: You do NOT have to play this game to fully understand the second two games in the series.

Now that that's out of the way. Is this a bad game? No, not at all. I would honestly rather give this a neutral rating. In the sea that is Artifex Mundi games this is however, on the lower end. It's old and despite being remastered, it shows its age. Now, that isn't really a bad thing and not why I feel meh about this game. It's the storyline.

All of the games are about the time traveling Ambrose family, except the events this game have very little connection to the other two. Some things are mentioned and two of the characters do show up again but not the main character which I found disappointing. At the end it seems like she's going to go on exciting adventures and...nope. Not to mention, the story was a little confusing, had plot holes and left me with more questions than answers. If you DO play this game then you should play the other two in the series, they will help answer some of the questions left by this one.

All that aside, because of the storyline and rather dull mini games I found playing this a chore. Sure, the hidden object scenes were beautiful and fun but having to collect things to time travel got tedious. Not to mention, the odd lighting effects hurt my eyes and caused me to strain them a bit.

My other pet peeve were the cut scenes and how their mouths moved, would have been better to not move at all. However, that isn't such a big deal so I got used to it. It's an older game so some allowances are to be made. Like Micheal sounding like he was voiced by Microsoft Sam.

Overall, the other two Time Mysteries games are better and stronger story wise. This game isn't bad but it's also not good. Play it if it's on sale or in a bundle but I recommend just skipping to the other games in the series for a better experience.

[url=http://lunarproductions.tumblr.com/]Lunar Productions[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198138504258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1441997739}
review: El peor juego de objetos ocultos al que he jugado, ni te cala por su historia, hay muchos elementos absurdos que te sacan de la misma, ni esta bien realizado. No lo recomiendo

author: {'steamid': '76561198016427463', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1439411254}
review: This game is very outdated, even for its original date of release. The hidden object puzzles were blurry and had a dreadful ray of light effect that made it difficult to even see anything. It took me about 3 days to complete the game because I couldn't play more than a few hidden object puzzles at a time. They were headache-inducing! The thing is, that when this game was originally released, games like Mystery Case Files: Dire Grove and Puppetmaster were already out and they were much more superior than this. This is why I can't recommend this game. Artifex Mundi has come a long way and their recent games have been amazing. This is definitely not the game to start out with.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981706607', 'num_games_owned': 4157, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1439081714}
review: Well, this game certainly shows how far Hidden Object Games have evolved.  Even with the remastering, this was painful to go through - the game uses a central hub so you get the same room with different objects numerous times; the sub-sections are rarely more than two screens, and the adventure portions are minimal. The alternative to the HOG sections is a collapse style game, which kind of works and kind of doesn't, and there are find the difference sections that are annoying.  And the Hidden Object scenes aren't very good either. All in all, the only reason to play this is to see how much better Artifax Mundi has gotten in their game design over the years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000557842', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1439045363}
review:
I've only played this and the Enigmatis games from this developer, but highly recommend skipping this and going straight for those. The story is always a bit contrived in these games, but this one's awful, with a structure that has you doing the same things over and over again. The voice acting is among the hammiest I've ever heard. 

The actual gameplay is ok, but somehow the hidden object scenes were less enjoyable than in other games - maybe the rest of it had just put me off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071705187', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1438700519}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198002506911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 415, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1438667843}
review: One of the first, if not the first Artifex Mundi hidden object games created and now remastered.  The remastered version of this game does not show off the best in graphics or sound.  The graphics try to be ultra realistic, but end up really showing contrast on the objects that should be hidden, while some other objects are way too deeply embedded to find without pixel hunting for objects.  This is rare, but it happens at times.  The puzzles are relatively easy, just like you should find in this type of game.  The story is simple, and not very interesting.  You find a crystal ball that helps you travel time.  You travel through time with a bag of rings and you lose hold of the bag of rings.  You must travel to different time in our history to find each individual ring, 8 of them.  This game is hilarious in the sense that the voice overs are way over the top.  Not sure if it was meant to be this way, or it just happened to be this way, but it made it funny, in a bad way.  Overall, it's still a decent hidden object game, so not a bad deal for the right price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142235822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1438467800}
review: Entertaining enough. But the hidden object scenes in the time lab ( or w/e it's called ) were very anoying. The light flashes almost gave me headaches. And don't mention the distorted faces when chars are talking. No fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032239028', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 411, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1438511635}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041856540', 'num_games_owned': 919, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1438534609}
review:
Wow this game is really bad :D I guess it's a very old example of the HOPA genre. (I'm not quite sure what makes this edition "Remastered" - if this edition is this bad quality, how bad must have been the original?!)

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ the music is always pleasant, even if not too fitting to the various eras we visit
+ handy silhouette tool for the HO scenes
+ I liked finding HOs on a stained glass window

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- very bad voice acting
- the art style weirdly mixes 2D paintings, 3D models and photos
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=491553043
- very bad animations ( = stretched and squashed heads of 2D painted characters, the effect is hilarious & creepy)
- the plot is full of unexplained leaps which the protagonist mostly just rolls along with, but which leave the player dumbfounded
- the HO scenes have bad quality graphics and sometimes need pixel-hunting. The worst offender:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=492144084
- items in the HO scenes are often incorrectly named, the same object is called 2-3 different names in various scenes
- several puzzle types repeat

[h1]Wtf:[/h1]
- you have to drug an ailing monk to steal his cross :D

[u][b]Verdict:[/b][/u] Artifex Mundi came a looong way since this game. I wouldn't pay money for this one, get it for free or as a bundle filler. Only play it if you want to get the achievements, otherwise there are tons of better quality and actually enjoyable HOPA games out there. Many of the best are from Artifex Mundi themselves, they evolved to be one of the best developers :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198028450654', 'num_games_owned': 5815, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1577980890}
review:
Ich spiele total gerne Wimmelbildspiele. Ich hatte mich vorhin noch einmal gefragt warum eigentlich. Ich glaube es liegt daran, dass sie nicht besonders anspruchsvoll sind, aber meistens eine recht interessante Story erzÃ¤hlen. Letzteres ist mir an Spielen soweiso immer am wichtigsten. Zudem ist es so, dass ich tÃ¤glich sicher 10-12 Stunden arbeite, meistens 6 Tage die Woche und Abends dann keine groÃŸe Lust mehr habe auf einen AAA Titel, sondern eher noch 1-2 Stunden vor der Daddelkiste entspannen will. Dann kommen solche Wimmelbildspiele immer gut bei mir an, weil sie eben nicht sehr schwer zu lÃ¶sen sind, ein entspanntes spielen also.

AuÃŸerdem stehe ich total auf das Thema Zeitreise, wie es auch Time Mysteries: Inheritance - Remastered thematisiert. Ich finde dabei jeden Ansatz interessant, denn hinter jedem Ansatz einer Zeitreise, des Gedanken an die MÃ¶glichkeit und wie man das umsetzen kÃ¶nnte steckt viel Nachdenken. Ich finde es dabei immer spannend mich auf diese Thematik einzulassen und der Phantasie der Entwickler nachzuerleben. Das fand ich in diesem Spiel sehr gut gelungen und weil ich eben auf diese ganze Zeitreise-Thematik stehe denke ich hatte ich besonders viel SpaÃŸ mit diesem Spiel. Vielleicht ist das bei Euch anders, wenn euch das Thema nicht interessiert, ist ja bei Wimmelbildspielen hÃ¤ufig der Fall, dass diese sehr StoryabhÃ¤ngig sind, denn das ist schlieÃŸlich bei der Art von Spielen auch das wichtigste. 

[url=mediennerd.de/neu-auf-steam/]Mehr STEAM Spiele die mir gefallen[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197971074683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1437297509}
review:
This is NOT the best HO game I have played. It started out pretty solid for a remake, but towards the end it got sloppy with scenes that were blurry, item definitions that were inaccurate (a pike is NOT a spear) and it also resorted to transparent or blending objects to find towards the end as well. This is not a problem except they didn't start doing it until more than half way through the game so it was unexpected. The puzzles are a bit simple and the story is OK but the end is a bit dodgy.

If you are willing to give it a break for being a really old game then it will be worth it for you to get it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059934690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1437126008}
review:
Probably one of the worst HOGs I've ever played; the art and music is up to standard but the rest falls flat on its face. The animation is poor, the voice-acting cringeworthy; the story almost non-existant (and predictable when it does occasionally show), and you have to do the same sequence of things every time you need to progress.

Although there is some sort of time-travel throughout the ages, there is absolutely no attempt at education of history. The protagonist (and, actually, every other character in the game as well), is unlikeable, overly dramatic, annoying and forgettable.

The puzzles were so-so.

3/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042831386', 'num_games_owned': 598, 'num_reviews': 627, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1433357154}
review:
[h1]Short version: 64%[/h1]
Not even the remastered edition can hide how aged the first Time Mysteries game is. Hidden object enthusiasts may welcome the classic difficulty level, but the game has little to offer past that.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
Time Mysteries 1: The Inheritance is one of (or is) the first hidden object games made by Artifex Mundi â€“ a developer who is by now associated with the best contemporary hidden object titles on the market.

Not even the remake can mask the typical rookie developer issues though, like low-resolution, pixelated pictures or amateurish cut-scenes, where the story progresses by making two character portraits talk to each other.
It also shows the great potential Artifex Mundi had even by then. The hidden object scenes use public assets, cheap item placement, and pixel hunting, yet they are unique and surprisingly enjoyable.

The cheesy story about a family of time travellers is full of hammy dialogues, and it is barely more than a quick excuse to use a bunch of different themes from early medieval times to early 20th century Paris. But this is where the trilogy (and Artifex Mundi) started, so Iâ€™d say get it for curiosityâ€™s and historyâ€™s sake.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072365101', 'num_games_owned': 5420, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1435444600}
review:
What a mindfuck?! In the ending scene, not a single sentence made a sense. It must have been created using some random words generator, because none Turing test passing capable entity could possibly write it...
But on the other side, it fits gameÂ´s poorly written story and shallow characters quite well. Ugly graphics (cthulhuoid head animations were bizzare) and non-inventive mechanics added - Artifex Mundi started as a quite crappy developer. Therefore I sincerely admire how they advanced to much higher level with their later games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969267147', 'num_games_owned': 7582, 'num_reviews': 572, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1434609482}
review:
This mediocre hidden-object is flawed, but still fun enough to give it a thumbs up.

I don't know about "remastered": the resolution is still very low, and it's stretched out for widescreen monitors with no option to fix it. The character animations are awful: faces are distorted and morphed to give the impression that they are speaking, but the result is somewhere between comical and terrifying. Another annoyance is that in some scenes you have a pulsating light effect. It adds no realism, and only makes it hard to find objects.

The voice acting isn't great, but isn't too terrible. The story is hokey but there are worse.

So, what's good about? The gameplay: there are many good hidden-object scenes and several nice puzzles. Fans of the genre will enjoy. For newcomers, there are much better HOGs out there.

Finally, I'd like to thank the developers for supporting Linux! It is much appreciated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087496218', 'num_games_owned': 959, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1434548731}
review: It is kind of short, the story is lacking and some of the search and find puzzles' graphics are just horrendous. Let's not even talk about the voice acting. Definitely an older game, hard to get through because of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966511621', 'num_games_owned': 1216, 'num_reviews': 609, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1434500212}
review:
Pro:
[list]
[*]The best music i've ever heard in a HOG.
[*]Hint & skip puzzle button.
[*]Lots of hidden object puzzles.
[*]Hidden object puzzles have sonar.
[*]Cheesier than a quattro formaggi pizza.
[*]Hilarious wobbly face animation.
[*]Terrible voice acting.
[/list] 
Con:
[list]
[*]Terrible voice acting.
[*]Some of the hidden object puzzles are too easy.
[*]Repeating hidden object puzzle features awful flashing light.
[*]About half of the hidden object puzzles are really ugly.
[*]Lots of annoying 'find the seven differences' puzzles.
[*]It features Merlin.
[*]A bit on the short side (2 hours).
[/list]
[b]Conclusion[/b]

On one hand, this is an obviously dated and weaker HOG by Artifex Mundi. On the other, it has lots of HOPs, great music and a story that's 'so bad that it's good'. Get it at a discount or in a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170994718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1495091882}

author: {'steamid': '76561198015845179', 'num_games_owned': 913, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1434339390}
review:
Remastered? Maybe if you were in era of 600x500 resolution...

Let's tackle the big point here first, this is the remastered edition which I assume to mean it's redone graphics and such. Firstly, even with redone graphics a lot of the hidden object scences look worse than a youtube video at lowest quality. This being said, that makes these hidden object scenes painful to play since it's so badly pixelated you can't tell what it is you're looking at! To top it off in hidden object scenes when you go back to the hub, they all have this weird glowy light effect that really hurts the eyes. I just resorted to using a guide from the internet for most of those scenes after a while.

In terms of plot, it's very one dimensional, father gets kidnapped -> chase bad guy to reclaim rings -> finds rings -> catch bad guy -> save father. It really doesn't get that much more shallow than that. The game also suffers from the same formula the entire game. Go to an area that usually has only two screens, find 1/7 of the rings, go back to hub, do a spot the difference mini-game, then play horrible lightest hidden object scene, rinse and repeat 7+ times. It just feel stale and very linear.

For characters and cut scenes... Well... it's different.... Basically they took the original hand drawn graphics and instead of remastering them they just di weird stretchy things to them to make them look animated. It just looks like they have a monster inside of them trying to transform them into something. Not to mention how their skull buldges and warps as they speak. Redone graphics there were actually really horrible as they were done very lazily.

Overall, skip this game, it's not a gret hidden object game nor will it entertain you very much. Great if you can get it in a bundle and want to kill some time but if you actually want some entertainment value, look at most of the other games Artifex Mundi has made.

Overall 3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198107000763', 'num_games_owned': 8307, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1434098428}
review:
The graphics are low-res and look rather stretched on HD screens. The "animations" are atrocious. The story is rather shallow and riddled with gaps. However if you played Time Mysteries II and III - then it's also worth to play this one. I bought it for the sake of ocmpletness and I'm not disappointed. The puzzles are pretty good and there's plenty of hidden-object scenes. After having played most of Artifex Mundi's games, I am under impression that puzzles and HO's in this game are harder than in most of them - which is definitely a good think. All in all, more pros than cons.

TL;DR Worth playing for puzzles and hidden object scenes, but lacks in the story and visuals.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009026799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1433887435}
review:
Having played other Artifex Mundi games before playing this one, it is very clear that this is one of their first games. The graphics are cruder, and you get absolutely no explanation as to what your goal is in any of the puzzles. It's kind of just like, "Hey you. Figure this out." Most of them aren't really super hard to piece together, but there were one or two that I was clueless on. Some of the dialogue seems like the wrong characters are saying it a couple of times, as well, and Michael's voice is rip-your-ears-off AWFUL. Be prepared to cringe. A lot. 

Overall, though, it's still an enjoyable game, and to some degree it's cool to see how far Artifex Mundi has come as a company, but it's definitely the lowest on my list of their games that I have played so far. I wish there was a "Meh" option for the recommendation, because I wouldn't absolutely recommend, but I didn't hate it either. So please take the recommendation with a grain of salt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090366497', 'num_games_owned': 710, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1433546536}
review:
It's.. okay.
The main problem is that by the standards of more current Artifex Mundi games... it's kinda rubbish.

The game itself is a hidden object game - where other games by this dev are a mix of point and click adventure and are fairly story heavy in this the storyline is a poor attempt to give you a reason for solving a seemingly endless stream of hidden object puzzles. The puzzles themselves are rather grainy which makes spotting certain images within them more difficult than they should be. The storyline... well to be honest it's awful and makes absolutely no sense at the end.

If you don't mind the terrible accents and grainy visuals and want something that is predominantly hidden object oriented rather than a mix of things then this may be an okay game to try. I wouldn't recommend it as an intro to Artifex Mundi games though as it hasn't aged all that well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027424772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1520552942}
review:
[b][u]Game Information[/u][/b]

"Time Mysteries: Inheritance" Remastered is an Hidden Object Puzzle Adventure game. The game was developed and published by Artifex Mundi.

"Inheritance" is the first episode of "Time Mysteries."

Even though the game is not labelled as a collector's edition, it has some extra feature that are not available in its' counterpart; the standard edition.

[b][u]The Game Review[/u][/b]

Game Visuals

I want to mention that the visuals in the game are nicely done. The visuals can be adjusted in the game's option menu.

Game Audio

I want to mention that audio for the game is well done. Even though the audio is somewhat simplistic and repetitive. The audio can be adjusted in the game's option menu as well.

Gameplay

There are two different difficulty modes to choose from: Regular and Expert.

The notebook keeps track of progression in the game. Such as story events and clues.

There is no padlock feature that is available to lock the inventory panel in place to make it stationary. The inventory panel comes automatically stationary.

The hidden object scenes consist of the following: Traditional word lists. Some of these hidden object scenes may require little or no interactions.

There is an optional mini-game: Match 3. It is only available during hidden object scenes.

The puzzles are fairly easy to solve without having the need to skip any of them.

There is a bonus chapter in the game. But it can be accessed only after the main story is completed.

There are ten different achievements that can be unlocked from playing the game. Each of these achievements does come with some requirements that need to be completed before they are unlocked.

Miscellaneous

There are six different trading cards to collect. Only three of those trading cards are given out by the game. There are several ways to get the rest of the trading cards: Purchased from the Steam's Community Market; Trade with friends; Booster Packs and its Booster Pack Creator.

Final thoughts: I have found the game enjoyable to a certain extent. The replay value for the game is low. I would recommend this game, but not at the game's full price value.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049582406', 'num_games_owned': 2048, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1433189190}
review:
I understand this is a re-release of an older game but the original game must have been so bad that this REMASTERED edition does nothing to improve on it.

PROS:

+ An old HOG that shows how bad this genre was 5 years ago.
+ Hilariously bad voice acting and dialog (?)
+ Nonsensical plot (?)
+ When people talk their heads are animated in a way they deform and look like they're going to explode, nice effect xD

CONS:

+ Low resolution graphics makes game harder.
+ Items are hidden using annoying tactics like: same color (white over white), different texture (a cup with wooden texture), a lot of the item obscured behind other items (that little end over there is a guitar!), ambiguous names.
+ Puzzles don't have instructions nor even a hint of what to do (in one or two you spend more time knowing what to do than actually doing it)
+ Re-used assets (there is one room you keep coming back 7 times to search hidden objects and every search for the difference round in between-rings is a room you've already been to)

I bought Artifex Humble Bundle because it was recommended to me as one of the best developers of this genre and I sincerely hope that the other games are better than this... I understand this is a re-release but if I was them I'd have remade it entirely because as it stands right now it is a disgrace that redeems itself only for its comedy value.

Anyway I'm looking forward to the other Artifex games! I hope they redeem themselves.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977594570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1433110708}
review:
Time Mysteries: Inheritance - Remastered is a re-release of an older hidden object game from HOG masters Artifex Mundi. While one of the weakest offerings by this developer in terms of quality, it's also one of the most (probably unintentionally) hilarious games of the bunch. The story and scenes are super cheesy, and the weird lipsynching animation and awful voice acting in parts really doesn't help matters. 

However, it still has some charm and mechanically it offers the same style of hidden object scenes and puzzles as the other A.M. titles, just not quite as polished. For example, I really found the lighting in some of the scenes, including the archive of artifacts you revisit over and over, really distracting. The dimming and brightnening light really just gave me a headache while I searched for objects.

The game is short and only takes a couple of hours to play through. Having played this game on another platform before it was available on Steam, I can't really say that I noticed much "remastering" and it pretty much looked exactly the same as it did as an app.

I'm still recommending the game, but only for hardcore HOG/AM fans and anyone that really likes a bit of cheese with their games from time to time.  Although it's definitely not essential to play through before continuing in the Time Mysteries series â€” which does improve drastically in quality through the sequels â€” it's kind of neat to see the story develop and I liked the way the third game went back to the central hub you first encounter in this game. Also, it offers easy achievements and trading cards, which is always nice for those who enjoy collecting those.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008107453', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1433020110}
review: I would recommend this only to people who love Artifex Mundi's other games. It's old and has quite a lot of flaws (to name the funniest one: a character saying another character's line), the story is "meh" and the game itself is pretty repetitive. I enjoyed it regardless, and if you like that kind of games, you'll probably enjoy this one as well. Just make sure to get it when it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982540582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1432933115}
review:
I've played through nine other Artifex Mundi titles to completion and have enjoyed them all, and I'd definitely recommend checking out anything else from their catalog.  This one, however, I don't think I could recommend to anyone but a die-hard Hidden Object game fan.

My main complaints are basically:
* The Hidden Object components are far more frequent than they typically are in other AM titles.  Other titles feel more like Adventure Games which happen to include HO puzzles, whereas this one is very much a HO game which happens to include a few extra elements.
* The central Museum area HO puzzles, which you'll apparently do seven times, are all set in the same room and feature a distracting throbbing-light effect
* Inclusion of spot-the-difference puzzles as well
* The interface is clunkier than their later offerings...  One specific problem I had was the 17th Century chemistry puzzle seemed to get locked in an unfinishable state, with the "Skip" counter no longer even moving forward (so I couldn't complete the puzzle, and also couldn't skip it), which was the final thing that led to my uninstallation.

On top of those, there was the typical absurd and nonsensical plot, which I can typically just roll with and enjoy for having the surreal fever-dream like atmosphere which other Artifex Mundi plots cultivate, but combined with the frustrations above, it didn't do anything for me.

So yeah: check out some other Artifex Mundi titles instead, especially if you're new to the genre.  The two "Grim Legends" titles are the ones I'd finished just before starting this one, and were superb examples of the genre, IMO.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960393604', 'num_games_owned': 2763, 'num_reviews': 243, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1432849557}
review:
This game is the epitome of shovelware.  Crank a game out as quickly as possible and with minimal regard for quality.  And I'm not saying that because it's a casual game, or even because it's a hidden item game.  I happen to like that genre, it's a great way to kill time.  But this particular game has problems with it.

Like other Artifex Mundi games (I have played several), this one does the "warping the image to simulate movement/talking".  The problem is, the effect looks really, really bad.  Particularly in this game, which seemed to be even worse than previous games I played.  There are at least two parts of the game where the wrong person reads a line.  A line clearly meant for someone else, yet it made it through the voice work and animation and nobody caught it.  That may well be that the reason for this is the developers are not native English speakers (Artifex Mundi is a Polish company).  This can also be evident a couple times where there are some awkward sentences, or where some of the 'hidden objects' are misnamed (there's one instance were a baseball is listed as a 'tennis ball', and another where - despite being correct, and specific, elsewhere in the game - a candle holder is merely labeled 'candle').

As for the hidden object puzzles themselves, there's a couple instances where the item you are looking far is drawn on something, but is done so lightly as to make it nearly impossible to see.  Also, unlike several other games from this developer, there is story mode... and that's it.  There is no bonus adventure, no area to repeat the puzzles, you have the play through which auto saves and nothing more.  On the plus side at least, the achievements for this game can actually be completed in a single play through (some other games prevent this from being the case).

As for the story aspect, it is pretty typical Artifex Mundi fare.  Something to drive the player forward, a reason to go from puzzle to puzzle.  And it works, you can 'care' enough to get through it.  However, the story completely gives up at the end.  To the point where it seems to forget that certain events have happened, shifts gears entirely, and ends abruptly with a bit of a hand wave.

If you really, really enjoy this genre, and don't mind some flaws in the story and presentation, then this is a perfectly serviceable game - if you can get it cheap.  But, even for fans of this developer, this game is not worth full price.  Especially not with such obvious and painful flaws proving that they don't care about their consumers, only their money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961553883', 'num_games_owned': 7378, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1431722581}
review:
This game is an updated version of one of Artifex Mundi's first HOG titles and it shows its age. Voice acting is not all that good, and at times the female protagonist speaks lines which are clearly meant for another character. Graphics are simply weird -- all the voiced dialog has the actors standing still while their heads deform --  and the story is not all that interesting.
But it's still an AM game, which means that it is a well made HOG game that fans of the genre will appreciate.

As for gameplay, most locations are limited to two or three screens with at most two puzzles. The collection style puzzles are extremely simple. The HOG puzzles make up for it with the standard AM detail though. If you don't like HOG puzzles or are just stuck and don't want to use the hint button, you can play another game instead like in their other titles. Instead of the dominos alternative that their newer titles have though, in this game you can do a strange match-3 game instead of playing the HOG puzzles.

Since it's such an old entry I find it hard to recommend to anyone but a real fan of the genre, or someone wanting to play the later titles of the series. It's not a bad game, but there are much better titles available from the same developer. Hold off until you can get a discount, or if you must play it since you want to play the later games in the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071132711', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1379, 'last_played': 1431314992}
review:
The mysterious time traveler reminds me of Captain Jack Harkness from Doctor Who. Don't judge. 

It's not awful and it's not good. If you have played the more recent Artifex Mundi's HOGs, you will find this one to be a drag. More hidden object than puzzle, which can get old fast. I find the music a bit repetitive compared to thier other games. You can tell this is one of their first games. Their newer games are EPIC compared to this one. The graphics are still pretty poor... in result, makes it very hard to find objects in the HOG parts. I don't hate it but I don't love it. Artifex has come a long way. Praise Elune!!

I recommend this game, because I feel like if you play this game you will appreciate the rest of Artifex's works.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046407276', 'num_games_owned': 6090, 'num_reviews': 233, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1433236759}
review:
[h1]Oh my, Fishheads.[/h1]

This game is one of the older Artifex Mundi games, and it might be more to the fans of either the company or at least for fans of hidden object games. The graphics aren't quite up to the standard you might have in mind when you hear the name Artifex Mundi. Also you might be surprised by the story and the jumble of the same. 

The HOGs are on a higher end scale of difficulty, the minigames inside have simple to difficult setting. All in all it's not the fare you might expect from an Artifex Mundi game. This said the game is not up to the general standard, at least at my computer it crashes quite regulary on the endgame. The story also is not the general standard of Artifex Mundis games, but that might be reasonable given that during the last years Artifex Mundi has done a lot to evolve the genre. 

I give a conditional recomendation: If you have other games of the Triology this might be a nice to have game, don't buy it just to try out the genre, it might get you on the wrong foot. For fans of the genre this is also a nice to have, not an requirement. Never forget that hidden object games are casual games, that means they can be played for a nice intermezzo during a break, or as a productivity relieve tool. This game might not be the perfect game, neither it is one of the best games I ever encountered - but it also isn't a lemon at all, just something in between... Like a bouillabaisse it can be satisfying and filling, but if you do eat too much of it you might just as well get violently sick.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995498874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1427822998}
review:
As a fan of Artifex Mundi, I can't really recommend this game, although there are some good points

The story is surprisingly the highlight of the game : the time travelling plot is funny at times and allows the player to explore a wide array of places and time periods. The voice acting is pretty good (the main character is voiced by none other than Lani Minella, who also voices Nancy Drew in the game series) and the music is pleasant

Unfortunately the game is very rough around the edges, and has way too many HO scenes, which becomes tiresome after a while.

Only buy this game if you want to support AM, or if you love HO games.

review:
Inheritance ist der erste Teil der Time Mysteries-Triologie, die fÃ¼r Steam neu aufgelegt wurde. Da das Spiel etwas Ã¤ter ist, merkt man ihm es im Vergleich zu Teil II und III natÃ¼rlich an - Man wird deutlich holpriger in die Story geworfen, deren Ende auch sehr schnell (in Runde 4 Stunden inklusive aller Erfolge )erreicht ist.
Dennoch ist das Spiel als solches gut gemacht, es hat spannende Minispiele und RÃ¤tsel, die Wimmelbilder sind auch gut gemacht. Die Objekte waren in den meisten FÃ¤llen richtig bezeichnet, nur dass der "FÃ¤cher" mehrmals als "Ventilator" betitelt wird ist unverstÃ¤ndlich und irritierend.
Insgesamt ist Inheritance sicherlich kein Ãœberflieger - dies liegt aber auch daran, dass dieses Spiel deutich Ã¤lter ist als die meisten Anderen, die hier auf Steam angeboten werden. Gut, spielens- und empfehlenwert ist es aber allemale, gerade fÃ¼r einen reduzierten Preis kann man es sich definitiv holen!

review: So poorly done. The story, the graphics, the puzzles, the actors. Horrible!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970887820', 'num_games_owned': 4531, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1425401736}
review: This is a tough one as I know this is quite an older game but even counting that, this is by far the weakest Artifex Mundi game I have played. The story really isn't very engaging and while a good effort has been made to update the graphics its still very obvious this was one of Artifex Mundi's first titles. There is some fun to be had with the hidden object scenes and the puzzles are ok though a little on the easy side. A few scenes in the end (Im looking at you haberdashery) were still quite muddy even at high res, making some objects a little hard to find. Look, I had some fun with the puzzles in this and Im going to give it a recommendation with caveats. If you have never played an Artifex Mundi game go and nab Ghosts of Maple Creek or Nightmares From the Deep: The Cursed Heart instead. If you have all their games already, just go into this one aware that its showing its age.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024920171', 'num_games_owned': 880, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1425331858}
review: This is probably the weakest of the Artifex Mundi hidden object games that I've played. It's a bit shorter and more repetitive, with fewer extras (e.g. no bonus chapter or collectibles). Still, I had a good time playing it, and that's what counts the most, I suppose.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025823574', 'num_games_owned': 3339, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1425223053}
review:
A short version: 
This game is kind of outdated. It was done with Mundi's older engine back in 2010, and is amongst their first games. It's not a bad game, but their other games outclass it by far - this is not a good game to start with because it's really rough at the edges.
I can only suggest it to players who can tolerate lousy graphics, bad voice acting, a story which- by the way fits quite well into the trilogy - weak on it's own.  It's a good example to see in what way and how HOGs (Hidden Object Games)  of Artifex Mundi changed in the past years.

Little more in-depth:
I can't value this game as other games of Mundi - because this is a really early one and based on my experience with their newer games, they improved vastly.  Take this into consideration, please - the list is more of an informative guide to the game, I don't want to bash at it.
Playing this game made me fell the same like when you go into a museum that houses some really old artifacts. They are not nice; not as sharp, as new, as fancy, as decorated or even as detailed as the new ones. Facing facts: they are worse. But it's intresting to see that this existed,  and this is how something started.

For example the facial gestures are - no better word - creepy. I think they were made with a technique that renders the 3D face but shows it in a 2D setting. Because meanwhile there are no strong outlines presented (They went for the realistic feeling, not the cartoonish way) it looks like you would see a person's face with a bad stereopsis. It looks really strange compared to newer HOG games but at the same time - I've never seen this animation, so it was really intresting to see a new (at least for me) way of presentation.
Voice acting sadly was really lacking - at lots of points I had a feeling that a program read out the lines, not even a living person :\
The game's system and the order of objectives are also really rudimentary. For example you arrive to a monastery and immediately pops up an objective: get medicine for the priest you haven't even talked to.
And finally an aspect I'd love to see in upcoming games: really creative hidden object scenes and puzzles. I've had to find items in paitings, rock-carvings, murals, even roseglasses.  There was also two puzzles when you had to solve a tangram-puzzle and two when you had to slide boxes to get one bigger box out of the grid.  I really do hope at least the tangram ones will come up again in never games :)
Probably you realized at this point if you want this game or not. If haven't - I'm sure it was a great HOG in it's time, but in today's standards, it's rough - like the rock in the ocean that will turn into a round pebble with enough time.
I felt that I have to give a negative recommendations because this game is a nieche one - I could only recommend it for comitted hidden object gamers, most of other, new gamers to the genre would felt cheated if they would buy this game on my recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993973183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1433185644}
review:
Der erste, nun in einer aufbereiteten Version vorliegende Tei der "Time Mysteries"-Reihe schlittert fÃ¼r mich knapp an einer Kaufempfehlung vorbei. Damit sage ich nicht, das Spiel sei schlecht, aber ich kann es - angesichts der Konkurrenz auch aus dem eigenen Hause Artifex Mundi - nur Sammlern empfehlen, die auch schon die Folgeteile gespielt haben und das Trio vollstÃ¤ndig haben wollen. (Wobei meines Wissens der einzige innere Konnex nur die Familie Ambrose ist, nicht die Figuren oder Handlung)

Ich habe den Eindruck, als sei ein 'altes' Spiel nur halbherzig aufpoliert worden, um Steam-tauglich zu werden. Es fÃ¼hlt sich aber ganz und gar nicht wie eine NeuverÃ¶ffentlichung an und ist graphisch nicht auf dem Level aktueller Releases von Artifex Mundi. Vielmehr spielt es sich -und sieht auch ein bisschen so aus- wie ein Wimmelbild-Spiel, das in einer Compilation beim Discounter oder in einem Elektromarkt verscherbelt wird.

Die Wimmelbilder sind zum Teil etwas unfair, dafÃ¼r sind die Minispiele (selbst fÃ¼r jemanden wie mich, der in anderen Spielen hÃ¤ufig "auflÃ¶sen" lassen muss) sehr einfach. Ãœber Mastermind, RÃ¶sselsprung, Anordnung von Zutaten nach Rezept, Finde-sieben-Unterschiede und ein Murmelbahn-Spiel ging es bislang nicht hinaus. Ãœber ein simples Nebeneinander von Wimmelbild- und Minispiel, etwa in die Richtung echter Adventure-Problemstellungen, wie sie sich beim Thema Zeitreise anbieten wÃ¼rden und wie sie aktuelle Releases von Artifex Mundi bieten, kommt dieser Teil nicht heraus: jede Zeitzone besteht aus zwei bis drei RÃ¤umen, ein eingesammelter Gegenstand kann sofort eingesetzt werden, und ab geht es in die "Zentrale", wo man sich (wieder in zwei RÃ¤umen) auf die nÃ¤chste Zeitzone vorbereitet. Erst den gerade erworbenen Ring in die Maschine geben, dann GegenstÃ¤nde der betreffenden Zeit suchen, aktivieren ... und weiter.

Graphisch macht "T.M. - Das Erbe" einen durchwachsenen Eindruck. Positiv mÃ¶chte ich hervorheben, dass es erfrischend ist, sich "historische" GemÃ¤lde oder Gobelins zu durchsuchen. Was freilich gleich wieder den Nachteil hat, dass die Macher leicht unfair werden mussten, indem sie in diesen historischen Bildern an unmÃ¶glichen oder unlogischen Stellen die zu suchenden GegenstÃ¤nde mehr verhehlen als verstecken.
Die in der Ur-Version sicher statischen Dialog-Szenen wurden (nicht sehr sorgfÃ¤ltig) animiert, was objetiv SCHLIMMER aussieht als wenn man sie starr gelassen hÃ¤tte, da nur eine Art Verzerrungsfilter Ã¼ber die Gesichter gelegt wird. Es sieht weniger nach einem Gesicht in einem GesprÃ¤ch aus und mehr nach einem Gesicht, das auf einen Luftballon gemalt wurde, welcher dann ein wenig verformt, geknetet und gestaucht wird.

Als letzten Kritikpunkt (und hier bin ich wahrscheinlich ein bisschen pÃ¤pstlicher als der Papst) mÃ¶chte ich auf die vielen Anachronismen hinweisen, die gerade in einem Spiel, das sich so intensiv mit den verschiedenen Zeitebenen befasst, nicht wirklich vorkommen dÃ¼rfen. Dabei spreche ich nicht von GegenstÃ¤nden, die es in der entsprechenden Zeit (... so...) nicht geben kann (was allenfalls damit zu erklÃ¤ren wÃ¤re, dass man ja einem Mann hinterher jagt, der ebenfalls durch die Zeit reist und ggf. Sachen hinterliess), sondern mit echten Anachronismen wie *vÃ¶llig* falscher Musik oder Erfindungen, die damals noch nicht gemacht wurden.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971532357', 'num_games_owned': 2752, 'num_reviews': 413, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1425213014}
review:
Finally, with this game, I can understand the Time Mysteries series! It's true that I was missing something when I played the sequels. And at least, I get more time travelling here, even if it's each time two scenes. The HOG scenes are more present, a testimony from the transition from pure HOG like it was years ago to a more complex game. And the soundtrack is really good, fitting each era.

While I loved the game, I just disappointed in the animation of the faces. It wasn't feeling natural. Sir Bodwin particularly was kinda... how to tell... weird.

Anyway, it's a good game from Artifex Mundi, that I was waiting with impatience. It didn't disappoint me at all. But for a more challenging game, set your eyes on the sequels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073445985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1425002993}
review: I'm rating this a 6/10, or a very mild recommend.  Keep in mind that it's one of Artifex Mundi's first games, just updated and remastered so they could release it on Steam.  It's simple and a bit rough around the edges, with a simpler story than those their most recent releases have evolved into having, no bonus chapter, and no collectibles/clickables.  But for those who appreciate their games and enjoy the Time Mysteries series, it's worth picking up on a sale for a quick playthrough and a look at one of their earlier releases.  It's about 2-3 hours to play through it.
